sentence: A lthough rebounding construction and home-renovation markets have gone through some swings in recent months, most of the news has been pretty good.
That bodes well for companies that supply products to the building industry, whether you're talking about nail manufacturers or makers of high-end heating and air-conditioning systems.
It's especially good for companies that provide a wide range of products to a wide range of markets.
One of those companies isMasco ( MAS ), whose product lineup includes everything from cabinetry and paint to faucets, windows, fasteners, decorative hardware, coating systems and hot tubs.
It also provides installation and other services.
The name "Masco" might not ring a bell.
But chances are you know some of its brands, which include Behr paint, Delta faucets and KraftMaid cabinets.
The company's website lists 20 different companies under its corporate umbrella.
It sells its products directly to dealers, through wholesale channels and at home-improvement retailers such asHome Depot ( HD ) andLowe's ( LOW ).
Rebounding construction markets in North America and elsewhere have helped Masco run off 13 straight quarters of double- or triple-digit EPS gains.
It reported 2015 first-quarter results on April 28.

Though the performance didn't blow anybody's socks off -- Masco met consensus earnings views but fell short on revenue -- the company's stock price still rose 2.5% to 26.94 on the day it posted Q1 results.
Shares hit a multiyear high of 27.46 on Monday but have since fallen back and currently trade near 26.

Masco's strong recent stock performance -- like the performances of others in IBD's Building-Construction Products/Miscellaneous group, includingMohawk Industries ( MHK ) andAcuity Brands ( AYI ) -- is mainly due to bullishness over construction markets, analysts say.
"The entire building-products industry continues to move up," said James Armstrong, analyst at Vertical Research Partners.
"People seem to want to invest in housing.
They're looking for different ways to do it, and Masco is a stable way to do it."
In a recent note, Zacks Equity Research said demand for Masco's products "has been benefiting from an increase in new home construction and home-improvement activities in North America.
The repair and remodel market recovery is also gaining traction.
These tailwinds are driving revenue increases."
Masco officials declined to comment for this story.

On a Q1 conference call, CEO Keith Allman said his company's expectation is that U.S. housing starts will reach about 1.1 million units this year, down from earlier estimates of 1.3 million to 1.5 million.
Even with only 1.1 million starts, "that's a good, healthy 10% growth for us," Allman said.
"From a macro perspective, we continue to be very positive."
During its first quarter, Masco posted earnings of 20 cents a share and revenue of $2.02 billion.
Those figures were up 33% and 3%, respectively, from the prior year.
Operating margin came in at 9% -- its "strongest first quarter operating margin since 2007," Allman said.
North American sales climbed 5% to $1.64 billion as an improving U.S. economy helped drive demand for repair, remodeling and new home construction.
International sales declined 8% to $377 million, mainly because of negative currency translation due to the weaker euro vs. the U.S. dollar.
The unfavorable foreign-exchange rates pushed sales of plumbing products down 1% year-over-year to $796 million.
However, organic revenue rose 8%, driven by growth in the wholesale channels.
"The plumbing business is seeing good, strong sales in Europe," analyst Armstrong told IBD.
"That market continues to do well, and you're seeing good margins in that business."

Masco also saw solid growth in its Installations and Other Services segment as well as in Decorative Architectural, which benefited from a strong performance by the BehrPro line of professional painting supplies and services.
Less successful has been Masco's Cabinets and Related Products segment.
It saw Q1 revenue rise 5% year-over-year, but it posted an operating loss of $2 million.
The segment featured "high-single-digit growth at Kraftmaid due to strength in the retail and dealer channels," JPMorgan analyst Michael Rehaut noted.
However, Masco management "pointed to continued challenges" with its Merillat cabinetry brand in the dealer channel.
Armstrong calls cabinetry "a very lackluster segment" right now.
"They are continuing to improve it," he said, citing the February appointment of Joe Gross as the new president of Masco's cabinetry business.
"But we are going to have to see if that business picks up in the next few quarters.
If time moves on and the performance doesn't improve, management will be under pressure to figure out what to do with that segment."
That includes getting out of the business altogether, Armstrong added.
"They don't say much about it," he said, "but that possibility has to at least be on the table if they don't see improvements over the next two to three years."
In the meantime, analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect Masco to post annual EPS growth of 22% in 2015 and 26% in 2016.
The company also plans to repurchase $400 million to $500 million of shares this year.
The views and opinions expressed herein are the views and opinions of the author and do not necessarily reflect those of Nasdaq, Inc.
